{"abstract": "HSBC Holdings, the European bank, said it would buy part of an office tower in Shanghai to house its China headquarters as it speeds up expansion in China. HSBC agreed to buy naming rights and occupy 20 floors of one of the twin towers of the Shanghai International Finance Center, to be completed by 2010, from Sun Hung Kai Properties, HSBC said in a statement to the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. The tower, a few blocks from the bank\u2019s current headquarters, would be renamed HSBC Building-Shanghai IFC. Stephen K. Green, the chairman of HSBC, disclosed the deal at a news conference in Shanghai, but he declined to say how much the bank had agreed to pay.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/26/business/worldbusiness/26fobriefs-HSBCTOBUYPAR_BRF.html", "snippet": "HSBC Holdings, the European bank, said it would buy part of an office tower in Shanghai to house its China headquarters as it speeds up expansion in China. {"abstract": "The Citic Securities Company, the Asian brokerage firm, said first-half profit rose more than fivefold as a surging Chinese stock market fueled share trading and underwriting fees. Net income rose to 4.2 billion yuan ($554 million), from last year\u2019s 775.8 million yuan, Citic said. Brokerage commissions at Citic, which is based in Beijing, rose sixfold, to 6.6 billion yuan, in the first half. Citic Securities made 473 million yuan, or 4.4 percent of its revenue, from arranging share sales in the first half. Its investment banking division is the leading underwriter this year, with 20.1 percent of the market. Citic and its units have 165 branches and more than 5,000 employees.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/15/business/worldbusiness/15fobriefs-PROFITATBROK_BRF.html", "snippet": "The Citic Securities Company, the Asian brokerage firm, said first-half profit rose more than fivefold as a surging Chinese stock market fueled share trading and underwriting fees. {"abstract": "The Agricultural Bank of China, saddled with $100 billion of bad loans, may move some of its 14,500 rural branches to independent companies to speed up a government bailout and sell shares for the first time. The bank, one of the nation\u2019s largest, was established in 1979 to serve China\u2019s 800 million farmers. The Ministry of Finance and the China Investment Company, an agency set up last month to manage $200 billion of the nation\u2019s foreign exchange reserves, would each own a third of Agricultural Bank, according to a draft of a government proposal obtained by Bloomberg News. Another 20 percent would be sold to foreign investors that have experience with rural lending, and about 5 percent to local corporate investors, according to the document. The remainder would be offered to the public. China has spent about $500 billion bailing out its biggest lenders over the past decade.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/11/business/worldbusiness/11fobriefs-china.html", "snippet": "The Agricultural Bank of China, saddled with $100 billion of bad loans, may move some of its 14,500 rural branches to independent companies to speed up a government bailout and sell shares for the first time. {"abstract": "The United States should start running a federal budget surplus, and consider refinancing some of its existing debt to China.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/01/business/01views.ready.html", "snippet": "The United States should start running a federal budget surplus, and consider refinancing some of its existing debt to China.", "lead_paragraph": "Cheap money from China helped create the debt-fueled investment bubble that has now burst spectacularly. Beijing\u2019s policy of keeping its currency artificially low allowed it to rack up huge trade surpluses \u0097 cash that was recycled to help Americans live beyond their means. The Group of 20 leaders gathering in London ought to be focusing on preventing such imbalances in the future. {"abstract": "The Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, or ICBC, said it was now the world\u2019s largest bank by deposits after clients invested another 950 billion yuan ($140 billion) in the first quarter. Deposits rose to 8.9 trillion yuan as of March 31; including deposits from financial companies, the amount was 9.78 trillion yuan ($1.43 trillion), the bank said in a statement. ICBC overtook JPMorgan Chase and Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group of Japan, according to the statement. JPMorgan had $1 trillion in deposits at the end of 2008, while the Japanese lender held $1.29 trillion as of March 31, 2008, according to Bloomberg data.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/14/business/global/14fobriefs-BANKSAYSITIS_BRF.html", "snippet": "The Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, or ICBC, said it was now the world\u2019s largest bank by deposits after clients invested another 950 billion yuan ($140 billion) in the first quarter. {"abstract": "The Wuhan Iron & Steel Group, a Chinese steelmaker, agreed to pay $400 million for a stake in Brazil\u2019s MMX Mineracao e Metalicos to broaden its supply of iron ore.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/01/business/global/01fobriefs-CHINESEBUYST_BRF.html", "snippet": "The Wuhan Iron & Steel Group, a Chinese steelmaker, agreed to pay $400 million for a stake in Brazil\u2019s MMX Mineracao e Metalicos to broaden its supply of iron ore.", "lead_paragraph": "The Wuhan Iron & Steel Group, a Chinese steelmaker, agreed to pay $400 million for a stake in Brazil\u2019s MMX Mineracao e Metalicos to broaden its supply of iron ore. Wuhan Steel, based in Hubei province, will appoint two board members to MMX and become the second-biggest shareholder of the Brazilian company with a 21.52 percent stake, the Chinese company said. MMX, which is based in Rio de Janeiro, has a market value of 3.7 billion reais ($2.1 billion), according to Bloomberg data. China, the world\u2019s biggest steel producer, is investing in iron-ore projects globally to reduce dependence on Vale, the Rio Tinto Group and BHP Billiton. Wuhan Iron and EBX, MMX\u2019s holding company, also signed an accord to build a steel plant in Brazil, said a Wuhan Steel spokesman, Bai Fang. {"abstract": "The Agricultural Bank of China, one of the nation\u2019s biggest lenders, will sell a 15 percent stake in what may be the world\u2019s largest initial public offering on record.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/05/business/global/05bizbriefs-AGRICULTURAL_BRF.html", "snippet": "The Agricultural Bank of China, one of the nation\u2019s biggest lenders, will sell a 15 percent stake in what may be the world\u2019s largest initial public offering on record.", "lead_paragraph": "The Agricultural Bank of China, one of the nation\u2019s biggest lenders, will sell a 15 percent stake in what may be the world\u2019s largest initial public offering on record. The state-owned bank plans to sell 22.235 billion shares in Shanghai and 25.411 billion shares in Hong Kong, excluding an over-allotment option, according to a prospectus posted on the securities regulator\u2019s Web site Friday. Agricultural Bank will compete for investors\u2019 money with publicly traded rivals that plan to raise a combined $32 billion in stock and bond sales even with bank valuations near record low levels. Agricultural Bank will have 26.73 billion shares outstanding in Hong Kong after the offering, which includes 25.411 billion shares sold to the public and another 1.32 billion shares held by China\u2019s national pension fund. The prospectus did not give a price range for the share sale or an amount that the lender would seek to raise. China\u2019s securities regulator said it would review the plan on June 9. {"abstract": "A conversation with Dan Breznitz and Michael Murphree, authors of \u201cRise of the Red Queen,\u201d who say seeking small innovations in manufacturing, not breakthroughs, would be to China\u2019s advantage.", "web_url": "https://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/08/04/moving-china-up-the-value-chain/", "snippet": "A conversation with Dan Breznitz and Michael Murphree, authors of \u201cRise of the Red Queen,\u201d who say seeking small innovations in manufacturing, not breakthroughs, would be to China\u2019s advantage.", "lead_paragraph": "SHANGHAI \u2014 In \u201cRun of the Red Queen,\u201d a new book about China\u2019s innovation drive, Dan Breznitz and Michael Murphree lay out a contrarian view of this country\u2019s path. {"abstract": "Events this week have forced the French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, and Angela Merkel, the chancellor of Germany, to become mired in Greek politics.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/03/business/global/03iht-group03.html", "snippet": "Events this week have forced the French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, and Angela Merkel, the chancellor of Germany, to become mired in Greek politics.", "lead_paragraph": "FRANKFURT \u2014 The Group of 20 summit meeting in Cannes was supposed to be a chance for Europe and the event\u2019s host, President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, to shine. {"abstract": "Also, some hard-edged tweets attacking Ron Paul from Rick Perry\u2019s son, and Michelle Obama joins Twitter.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/13/the-breakfast-meeting-colbert-for-president-and-iphone-riots-in-china/", "snippet": "Also, some hard-edged tweets attacking Ron Paul from Rick Perry\u2019s son, and Michelle Obama joins Twitter.", "lead_paragraph": "The political performance art known as the Stephen Colbert campaign for president came a step closer to reality last night on \u201cThe Colbert Report\u201d on Comedy Central, as Mr. Colbert transferred control of his \u201csuper PAC\u201d \u2014 Americans for a Better Tomorrow, Tomorrow \u2013 to his friend and late-night lead-in Jon Stewart, Brian Stelter reported. Mr. Colbert\u2019s lawyer explained: \u201cYou cannot be a candidate and run a super PAC. {"abstract": "In February, home prices were lower in 27 of 70 Chinese cities surveyed compared with a year earlier, the country\u2019s statistics bureau said.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/19/business/global/home-prices-fall-in-chinese-cities-report-says.html", "snippet": "In February, home prices were lower in 27 of 70 Chinese cities surveyed compared with a year earlier, the country\u2019s statistics bureau said.", "lead_paragraph": "Home prices in China posted the worst performance in a year in February, the country\u2019s National Bureau of Statistics said Sunday, with the prices in almost half of the cities monitored by the government falling from a year ago as China maintained curbs on the property market.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "3", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Data Shows Home Prices Fall in China", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Data Shows Home Prices Fall in China", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Real Estate and Housing (Residential)", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Politics and Government", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "China", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2012-03-19T01:29:13+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Global Business", "byline": {"original": "By Bloomberg News", "person": [{"firstname": "Bloomberg", "middlename": null, "lastname": "News", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/740975ac-fd16-5e92-8b41-71d9571e5707", "word_count": 175, "uri": "nyt://article/740975ac-fd16-5e92-8b41-71d9571e5707"}

{"abstract": "People in the developed world are more likely to say that China is the world\u2019s leading economic power, whereas people in the developing world \u2014 and the Chinese \u2014 are more likely to say the United States is.", "web_url": "https://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/06/15/putting-chinas-economic-power-in-perspective/", "snippet": "People in the developed world are more likely to say that China is the world\u2019s leading economic power, whereas people in the developing world \u2014 and the Chinese \u2014 are more likely to say the United States is.", "lead_paragraph": "In January, David Leonhardt noted a finding that more Americans said China was the world\u2019s leading superpower than said the United States was. {"abstract": "A Chinese company defaulted on its bonds and was kicked off Nasdaq because it would not answer questions about its business. But its share price has risen 492 percent. The transition to Mr. Xi from Hu Jintao appears to have been messy, given both the Bo Xilai scandal and the machinations of former leader Jiang Zemin, but Mr. Hu no longer has any formal party positions and the handover was, at least on paper, the cleanest in the history of the People\u2019s Republic of China. {"abstract": "The year is ending on a strong note for the movie industry, with the number of tickets sold increasing by more than 5 percent; Bill O\u2019Reilly is finding great success in telling the story of the assassinations of Lincoln and Kennedy; Amazon is purging users\u2019 book reviews that seem to betray a conflict; and more.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/12/24/the-breakfast-meeting-hollywoods-2012-comeback-and-reviewing-amazons-reviews/", "snippet": "The year is ending on a strong note for the movie industry, with the number of tickets sold increasing by more than 5 percent; Bill O\u2019Reilly is finding great success in telling the story of the assassinations of Lincoln and Kennedy; Amazon is purg...", "lead_paragraph": "Movie attendance was up 5.6 percent, despite a weak summer, punctuated by mass killings at a screening in Aurora, Colo., of the latest Batman feature, Brooks Barnes writes. Ticket revenue at North American theaters is projected to jump by 6 percent, to $10.8 billion, according to an analysis by Hollywood.com. In 2012, industry executives say, the increase from foreign sales was even more critical, salvaging the prospects of movies that were mild disappointments in the United States like \u201cIce Age: Continental Drift,\u201d from 20th Century Fox, which made $68 million in China alone.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "The Breakfast Meeting: Hollywood\u2019s 2012 Comeback, and Reviewing Amazon\u2019s Reviews", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "persons", "value": "Dugard, Martin", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "O'Reilly, Bill", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "AMAZON.COM INC", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Lions Gate Entertainment Corporation", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Seventeen (Magazine)", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "China", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2012-12-24T15:00:26+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Noam Cohen", "person": [{"firstname": "Noam", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Cohen", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/30915e98-50b3-5aed-906b-1519b62f8129", "word_count": 624, "uri": "nyt://article/30915e98-50b3-5aed-906b-1519b62f8129"}

In an August report, the F.L.A. said Foxconn had carried out 284 of those improvements.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Improving Working Conditions at Foxconn", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Factories and Manufacturing", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "iPad", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "iPhone", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Fair Labor Assn", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Foxconn Technology", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Apple Inc", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "China", "rank": 7, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2012-12-26T22:22:45+0000", "document_type": "multimedia", "news_desk": "Business Day", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "", "person": [], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "Interactive Feature", "_id": "nyt://interactive/21b8f5ce-98b9-5ef4-98e8-96cf3deb148a", "word_count": 0, "uri": "nyt://interactive/21b8f5ce-98b9-5ef4-98e8-96cf3deb148a"}

{"abstract": "New rules will make it easier to monitor who is using the Internet there; the role of public libraries is expanding, with physical books becoming less central; also, remembering Gerry Anderson, who created the marionette-based British TV series \u201cThunderbirds.\u201d", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/12/28/the-breakfast-meeting-tighter-internet-rules-in-china-and-thunderbirds-creator-dies/", "snippet": "New rules will make it easier to monitor who is using the Internet there; the role of public libraries is expanding, with physical books becoming less central; also, remembering Gerry Anderson, who created the marionette-based British TV series \u201cT...", "lead_paragraph": "New rules issued by the Chinese government Friday will make it easier to monitor who is using the Internet and tamp down some of the vibrant discourse on the country\u2019s Twitter-like microblogs, Keith Bradsher reported. That discourse in recent weeks has publicized sexual and financial scandals that have led to the resignations or dismissals of at least 10 local officials, as well as accounts in Bloomberg News and The New York Times about the wealth of the country\u2019s top leaders. The rules, which come with much greater legal force than earlier regulations, require Internet users to provide their real names to service providers, while assigning Internet companies greater responsibility for monitoring what appears online. The government also included a mandate for businesses in China to be more cautious in gathering and protecting electronic data.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "The Breakfast Meeting: Tighter Internet Rules in China, and \u2018Thunderbirds\u2019 Creator Dies", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Computers and the Internet", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Libraries and Librarians", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "China", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2012-12-28T14:39:59+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Noam Cohen", "person": [{"firstname": "Noam", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Cohen", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/a496b050-7542-50af-b2f8-dc761e267b9b", "word_count": 388, "uri": "nyt://article/a496b050-7542-50af-b2f8-dc761e267b9b"}

{"abstract": "Hollywood studios negotiate their way through China\u2019s censorship process, Gigi Pritzker opens her own film production company, and Lance Armstrong confides in Oprah Winfrey.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/01/15/the-breakfast-meeting-hollywood-navigates-china-and-a-pritzker-heir-navigates-hollywood/", "snippet": "Hollywood studios negotiate their way through China\u2019s censorship process, Gigi Pritzker opens her own film production company, and Lance Armstrong confides in Oprah Winfrey.", "lead_paragraph": "As Hollywood studios look to tap into the fast-growing Chinese film market, they are increasingly having to navigate their way through that country\u2019s sometimes inscrutable censorship process, Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes write in The New York Times. As they do so, they are discovering some details and themes that won\u2019t pass muster, and that other things can be negotiated so that both the filmmakers and the Chinese censorship board are satisfied. Billions of dollars are riding on the outcome, because international box office revenue is such a crucial element in the success or failure of a picture. ", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "The Breakfast Meeting: Hollywood Navigates China, and a Pritzker Heir Navigates Hollywood", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Steroids", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "ARMSTRONG, LANCE", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Winfrey, Oprah", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Facebook Inc", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Wall Street Journal", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "China", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2013-01-15T14:23:07+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By The Editors", "person": [], "organization": "The Editors"}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/12684919-cba6-5f41-8476-7e91762006d7", "word_count": 387, "uri": "nyt://article/12684919-cba6-5f41-8476-7e91762006d7"}

[{"abstract": "The question is whether this will lead to greater political openness, an authoritarian clampdown to restore the veneer of stability, or social turmoil.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2013/01/22/appearance-of-consensus-is-breaking-down-in-china/", "snippet": "The question is whether this will lead to greater political openness, an authoritarian clampdown to restore the veneer of stability, or social turmoil.", "lead_paragraph": "GUANGZHOU, China \u2014 For two decades after the Tiananmen Square crackdown in 1989, China seemed on the surface like a country where free-market and even laissez-faire principles prevailed. {"abstract": "A consultant offers suggestions for small businesses that want to break into the Chinese market. Warning: \u201cYou can\u2019t beat the system.\u201d", "web_url": "https://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/01/23/have-you-tried-selling-in-china/", "snippet": "A consultant offers suggestions for small businesses that want to break into the Chinese market. Warning: \u201cYou can\u2019t beat the system.\u201d", "lead_paragraph": "A small-business guide we have just published quotes Savio S. Chan, who is president and chief executive of U.S. China Partners, a consulting firm that over the last eight years has helped nearly 100 American companies do business in China. {"abstract": "China, with $2.7 billion in ticket sales last year, passed Japan to become the second-biggest market for films, according to industry statistics.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/22/business/media/global-ticket-sales-for-movies-rise.html", "snippet": "China, with $2.7 billion in ticket sales last year, passed Japan to become the second-biggest market for films, according to industry statistics.", "lead_paragraph": "LOS ANGELES \u2014 Movie ticket sales around the world rose 6 percent last year, to $34.7 billion from $32.6 billion in 2011, as China became the world\u2019s second-biggest market for theatrical films after the United States, according to statistics released by the Motion Picture Association of America on Thursday.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "5", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Global Ticket Sales for Movies Rise 6%", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Global Ticket Sales for Movies Rise 6%", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Movies", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Motion Picture Assn of America", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "China", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2013-03-21T20:15:08+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Michael Cieply", "person": [{"firstname": "Michael", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Cieply", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/316ff084-c3a2-504e-b6c0-bf10c7d5417e", "word_count": 454, "uri": "nyt://article/316ff084-c3a2-504e-b6c0-bf10c7d5417e"}

{"abstract": "Another set of weak economic data out of China showed that fixed-asset investment slowed, industrial production grew less than projected and retail sales growth was driven almost entirely by consumers taking advantage of the drop in gold prices.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2013/05/13/as-chinas-economy-stumbles-government-eyes-reform/", "snippet": "Another set of weak economic data out of China showed that fixed-asset investment slowed, industrial production grew less than projected and retail sales growth was driven almost entirely by consumers taking advantage of the drop in gold prices.", "lead_paragraph": "Another week, another set of weak economic data out of China. Fixed-asset investment slowed and industrial production grew less than projected. {"abstract": "Beijing is taking incremental, but symbolic, steps toward financial reform, the author writes.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2013/07/22/signs-that-a-financial-overhaul-may-be-in-the-works/", "snippet": "Beijing is taking incremental, but symbolic, steps toward financial reform, the author writes.", "lead_paragraph": "Beijing announced an important if largely symbolic financial change on Friday. The People\u2019s Bank of China removed the floor on bank lending rates, a move that has been under discussion on and off for decades. {"abstract": "Yahoo does have some influence, the author notes. It has a representative on Alibaba\u2019s board and the right to appoint an investment bank to help run any offering process.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2013/07/30/why-an-alibaba-i-p-o-is-both-promise-and-problem-for-yahoo/", "snippet": "Yahoo does have some influence, the author notes. It has a representative on Alibaba\u2019s board and the right to appoint an investment bank to help run any offering process.", "lead_paragraph": "Alibaba is Yahoo\u2019s best investment, and its most frustrating problem. Its 24 percent stake in Alibaba, China\u2019s biggest online retailer, is probably worth more than Yahoo\u2019s entire booked assets of $16 billion. But a future initial public offering, in which Yahoo has promised to sell half its shares, may deliver much less. That is because Alibaba holds most of the cards.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Why an Alibaba I.P.O. {"abstract": "It took a great deal of time and effort for Deb Weidenhamer to get \u201cChinafied\u201d \u2014 but now she\u2019s trying to make it easier for other small companies.", "web_url": "https://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/09/04/what-does-it-take-to-do-business-in-china/", "snippet": "It took a great deal of time and effort for Deb Weidenhamer to get \u201cChinafied\u201d \u2014 but now she\u2019s trying to make it easier for other small companies.", "lead_paragraph": "We just published a Conversation With Deb Weidenhamer, chief executive of Auction Systems Auctioneers & Appraisers, an 18-year-old auction company with $135 million in annual revenue. The company is based in Phoenix, but two years ago, Ms. Weidenhamer set up shop in Shanghai, where her auctions offer Western manufacturers an easy way to export their goods, or simply test demand and learn about pricing. In this portion of the interview, she talks about what it has been like doing business in China \u2014 why she studies Mandarin 15 hours every week, how she got \u201cChinafied\u201d and how she can help other businesses get started there.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "What Does It Take to Do Business in China?", "kicker": "You're the Boss", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Auctions", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "International Trade and World Market", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Small Business", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Social Media", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "China", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2013-09-04T15:08:00+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Entrepreneurship", "byline": {"original": "By John Grossmann", "person": [{"firstname": "John", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Grossmann", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/b3f7998a-3ad5-556a-9047-4b84279bd5b3", "word_count": 1057, "uri": "nyt://article/b3f7998a-3ad5-556a-9047-4b84279bd5b3"}

{"abstract": "Alibaba and Tencent are making incursions into the country\u2019s financial services market and savers should be glad, the author writes.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2013/10/10/mobile-banking-players-are-shaking-up-chinas-cozy-oligopoly/", "snippet": "Alibaba and Tencent are making incursions into the country\u2019s financial services market and savers should be glad, the author writes.", "lead_paragraph": "The biggest threat to Chinese banks\u2019 cozy oligopoly may be in the hands of the nation\u2019s consumers. Two online companies, Alibaba and Tencent, are making incursions into the country\u2019s financial services market, providing an alternative to the capped deposit rates and sluggish service offered by the country\u2019s big lenders. {"abstract": "There are no official religious holidays celebrated in China, so the observation of Christmas there, where an American business owner has set up a subsidiary, requires explanation.", "web_url": "https://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/12/25/celebrating-christmas-in-china/", "snippet": "There are no official religious holidays celebrated in China, so the observation of Christmas there, where an American business owner has set up a subsidiary, requires explanation.", "lead_paragraph": "When I was a little girl, I raised money for missionaries who were taking Bibles into China. {"abstract": "My dog is always ready to move on and look for something new. I can relate.", "web_url": "https://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/01/16/what-i-miss-when-im-in-china-and-arizona/", "snippet": "My dog is always ready to move on and look for something new. I can relate.", "lead_paragraph": "My husband and I have a German shepherd mix named Raz that we rescued when he was a 9-month-old puppy. Today, Raz is always thrilled to go anywhere, whether it\u2019s to the park or to visit the vet. {"abstract": "A little more than a week into the New Year, our whole team returned to us \u2014 including one particular employee with a heartwarming story.", "web_url": "https://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/03/03/the-mystery-of-chinese-new-year-solved/", "snippet": "A little more than a week into the New Year, our whole team returned to us \u2014 including one particular employee with a heartwarming story.", "lead_paragraph": "In a recent post, I discussed an issue many Chinese companies cope with after New Year\u2019s break: the loss of staff members. "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/03/17/weibo-i-p-o-sets-a-low-bar-for-alibaba/", "snippet": "The growth of the Twitter-like Chinese microblog Weibo comes with some hairy regulatory risks, John Foley of Reuters Breakingviews writes.", "lead_paragraph": "Imagine the riskiest possible share offering. It would be a new, unprofitable company with rapid and uncertain growth in an emerging market. One whose customers are fickle, which lives under the constant threat of being snuffed out by regulators, and where external shareholders are dominated by insiders. The listing of Sina Weibo fits the bill. {"abstract": "Han Sanping is stepping down as chairman of the China Film Group, a government-sponsored company that supervises film imports to China.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/19/business/media/confirmation-of-shake-up-in-chinas-film-industry.html", "snippet": "Han Sanping is stepping down as chairman of the China Film Group, a government-sponsored company that supervises film imports to China.", "lead_paragraph": "LOS ANGELES \u2014 Even more mysterious than the subterranean power struggles in Hollywood are the hidden currents in China\u2019s growing film business. {"abstract": "A severe slowdown in China\u2019s economy would have a modest ripple effect, particularly on global commodity prices, but would not provoke a global crisis, two economists write.", "web_url": "https://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/03/27/chinas-shadow-banking-malaise/", "snippet": "A severe slowdown in China\u2019s economy would have a modest ripple effect, particularly on global commodity prices, but would not provoke a global crisis, two economists write.", "lead_paragraph": "Peter Boone is chairman of the charity Effective Intervention and a research associate at the Center for Economic Performance at the London School of Economics. He is also a nonresident senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics. Simon Johnson is a professor at the M.I.T. {"abstract": "Most leases stipulate that at the end of the term, the tenant must pay for the complete demolition of any improvements.", "web_url": "https://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/03/28/finding-office-space-in-china/", "snippet": "Most leases stipulate that at the end of the term, the tenant must pay for the complete demolition of any improvements.", "lead_paragraph": "If you open a business in China, you will require work space.\u00a0But there\u2019s a catch: To rent or lease a space, you need a business license. {"abstract": "There are three major differences between the way e-commerce works in the United States and in China.", "web_url": "https://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/07/07/learning-the-secrets-of-e-commerce-in-china/", "snippet": "There are three major differences between the way e-commerce works in the United States and in China.", "lead_paragraph": "There has been much buzz about the initial public offering of Alibaba, China\u2019s e-commerce giant. {"abstract": "For less than the price of a plane ticket to China, Export Now promised to ship a small business\u2019s goods to China and put them online in a massive market. {"abstract": "Careless assumptions about China have sent many Western companies, especially big multinationals, slinking back home.", "web_url": "https://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/12/11/be-skeptical-when-hiring-an-expert-on-china/", "snippet": "Careless assumptions about China have sent many Western companies, especially big multinationals, slinking back home.", "lead_paragraph": "I was recently invited to a restaurant in Shanghai to meet friends who were hosting an out-of-town guest from the West. {"abstract": "A slowdown in the pace of growth of China\u2019s economy is leading foreign investors to reassess the country as a destination for their money.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/21/business/international/to-invest-or-not-as-china-shifts.html", "snippet": "A slowdown in the pace of growth of China\u2019s economy is leading foreign investors to reassess the country as a destination for their money.", "lead_paragraph": "HONG KONG \u2014 On a tour of central Henan Province in May of last year, China\u2019s president, Xi Jinping, first raised the notion of the economy adjusting to a \u201cnew normal.\u201d Eight months later, with the economy growing at its slowest pace in more than two decades, it is increasingly clear what this adjustment will mean for China.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "To Invest, or Not, as China Shifts", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Economic Conditions and Trends", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "International Trade and World Market", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Foreign Investments", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "China", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2015-01-20T17:57:32+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "International Business", "byline": {"original": "By Neil Gough", "person": [{"firstname": "Neil", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Gough", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/5ff8d262-245b-5c64-b996-0bd25722269e", "word_count": 906, "uri": "nyt://article/5ff8d262-245b-5c64-b996-0bd25722269e"}

{"abstract": "Following the deal, BBVA will continue to hold a 4.7 percent stake in the Chinese bank.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2015/01/23/bbva-agrees-to-sell-stake-in-china-citic-bank-for-1-7-billion/", "snippet": "Following the deal, BBVA will continue to hold a 4.7 percent stake in the Chinese bank.", "lead_paragraph": "LONDON \u2013 The Spanish lender BBVA said on Friday that it had agreed to sell a 4.9 percent stake in China Citic Bank to the Chinese real estate developer Xinhu Zhongbao for 13.1 billion Hong Kong dollars, or about $1.7 billion.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "BBVA Agrees to Sell Stake in China Citic Bank for $1.7 Billion", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria SA", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "China International Trust & Investment Corp", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Citic Group", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "China", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2015-01-23T14:40:49+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Chad Bray", "person": [{"firstname": "Chad", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Bray", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/755e2d15-dc58-5135-943a-1b91fb69c609", "word_count": 138, "uri": "nyt://article/755e2d15-dc58-5135-943a-1b91fb69c609"}

{"abstract": "Sales in the United States and Canada fell about 5 percent in 2014, but in China they rose 34 percent.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/12/business/media/global-movie-ticket-sales-rise-1-as-china-surges.html", "snippet": "Sales in the United States and Canada fell about 5 percent in 2014, but in China they rose 34 percent.", "lead_paragraph": "LOS ANGELES \u2014 The world movie box office was up 1 percent last year from 2013, but ticket sales in the United States and Canada fell about 5 percent as growth became concentrated in China, the Motion Picture Association of America said on Wednesday.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Global Movie Ticket Sales Rise 1% as China Surges", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Business Briefing; Movie Ticket Sales Rise, Fueled by Growth in China", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "Motion Picture Assn of America", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Movies", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "China", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2015-03-11T20:25:34+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Michael Cieply", "person": [{"firstname": "Michael", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Cieply", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/f7bae454-7294-5b02-b3f8-72d24217b444", "word_count": 342, "uri": "nyt://article/f7bae454-7294-5b02-b3f8-72d24217b444"}

{"abstract": "Earnings have disappointed as copper and coal have tumbled. And looking forward, both rivals\u2019 behavior and Chinese demand remain unpredictable.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/20/business/dealbook/glencore-tripped-up-by-faith-in-rational-markets.html", "snippet": "Earnings have disappointed as copper and coal have tumbled. And looking forward, both rivals\u2019 behavior and Chinese demand remain unpredictable.", "lead_paragraph": "Glencore\u2019s shtick has long been that it is the master of the commodity markets. It knows when to take risks, it can shift supply to where it\u2019s most wanted and it tweaks its own mines to maximise profit. Or at least it can do all that when everyone else behaves rationally. That thinking has come unstuck, and the British-Swiss commodities trader\u2019s earnings have gone with it. They halved in the first six months of 2015.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Glencore Tripped Up by Faith in Rational Markets", "kicker": "Breakingviews", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Metals and Minerals", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Mines and Mining", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Commodities", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Coal", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Glencore International AG", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Xstrata", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "China", "rank": 7, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2015-08-19T19:47:51+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "DealBook", "byline": {"original": "By John Foley", "person": [{"firstname": "John", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Foley", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/024b1163-2bd2-5c58-bbef-7f9fb50cf659", "word_count": 347, "uri": "nyt://article/024b1163-2bd2-5c58-bbef-7f9fb50cf659"}

{"abstract": "The investment bank joins a long list of counterfeits that includes Apple stores and British villages. They\u2019re easy to mock, but they show an ingenuity and pluck that could be powerful.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/28/business/dealbook/a-fake-goldman-sachs-underlines-a-real-chinese-strength.html", "snippet": "The investment bank joins a long list of counterfeits that includes Apple stores and British villages. They\u2019re easy to mock, but they show an ingenuity and pluck that could be powerful.", "lead_paragraph": "The Goldman Sachs leasing company in Shenzhen is as genuine as the Apple store in Kunming and the $5 bottle of Ch\u00e2teau Lafite-Rothschild in Beijing. [{"abstract": "Try a few short problems from The Math League, an extracurricular activity used in China to balance the tedium of studying for the Gaokao, China\u2019s college entrance exam.", "web_url": "https://wordplay.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/08/31/mathleague/", "snippet": "Try a few short problems from The Math League, an extracurricular activity used in China to balance the tedium of studying for the Gaokao, China\u2019s college entrance exam.", "lead_paragraph": "The notorious Gaokao, (\u9ad8\u8003, or \u201cHigh Test\u201d) is China\u2019s SAT on steroids, with a score on the nine-hour test being the sole criterion for admission to Chinese universities. Preparing for the test is a\u00a0years-long\u00a0obsession for both students and parents. (In case you missed it: Brook Larmer\u2019s\u00a0Inside a Chinese Test-Prep Factory.) And for many, the unfortunate consequence is that the lengthy preparation destroys, rather than enhances, academic ability. {"abstract": "The falling renminbi may be a sign that China sees currency devaluation as a solution to its economic woes. Or maybe planners are losing their grip.", "lead_paragraph": "For the second time in less than six months, market turmoil in China is rattling the rest of the world. As in August last year, the trigger is a sudden slide in the value of the renminbi, which in turn has dragged down domestic stocks. {"abstract": "The United Steelworkers withdrew its petition to a trade panel after an industry group agreed to work with the union to address concerns over Chinese production.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/25/business/union-drops-effort-to-restrict-us-imports-of-raw-aluminum.html", "snippet": "The United Steelworkers withdrew its petition to a trade panel after an industry group agreed to work with the union to address concerns over Chinese production.", "lead_paragraph": "HONG KONG \u2014 The United Steelworkers union has suspended indefinitely an unusual effort to push the United States government to restrict all aluminum imports after the campaign ran into opposition from aluminum companies, the Canadian government and even Canadian members of the union.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Union Drops Effort to Restrict U.S. Imports of Raw Aluminum", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Aluminum", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "International Trade and World Market", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "United Steelworkers of America", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Customs (Tariff)", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "China", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2016-04-24T14:58:45+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Keith Bradsher", "person": [{"firstname": "Keith", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Bradsher", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/ac99db3b-4ef8-5f02-a09f-f048c142ef47", "word_count": 449, "uri": "nyt://article/ac99db3b-4ef8-5f02-a09f-f048c142ef47"}
